subject: RE: Re: [junit] Preventing JUnit from stopping on failures.

messageBody:
If this really is what you are doing, then JUnit probably is not the right
tool for the job.

JUnit works fine for large scale projects, but the tests should be small and
tightly focused, testing one small piece of functionality at a time. The
fact you need multiple independent assertions indicates your tests are
trying to test too much at once.

It definitely is not designed for testing GUIs in the manner you describe.
Abbot is good at testing GUIs, and is able to record scripts. It still
stops on a filed assertion, though. There are plenty of scripting tools
that do black-box testing. JUnit is not one of them.

--
Jim McMaster

Subject: Re: Re: [junit] Preventing JUnit from stopping on failures.


This is being implemented as a large scale project. Changing the software
"as it fails" is far from feasible, and more specifically, JUnit is being
used for black-box testing (ie manipulating GUI elements and comparing them
to BMP's etc).

Each "test" is implemented very simularly to a script. Click this GUI
button, compare this label to a BMP, etc.
